questions.question_text_1: What is the expected number of ice-creams that will be sold in any given bin? (Note: Enter the answer rounded to two decimal places. For example, if the answer is “1.234”, then enter it as “1.23”)

questions.question_text_1: If the tabulated value of the test statistic is 10.59, then which of the following statements are correct?
question_texts: If the tabulated value of the test statistic is 10.59, then which of the following statements are correct?

options.option_text: Reject the Null and conclude that the number ice-cream sold in Street-Bfollows a uniform distribution
Do Not Reject the Null and conclude that the number ice-cream sold in Street-B follows a uniform distribution
Reject the Null and conclude that the number ice-cream sold in Street-B doesnot follows a uniform distribution
Do Not Reject the Null and conclude that the number ice-cream sold in Street-B does not follows a uniform distribution

questions.question_text_1: A retailer has data pertaining to customers who visit the shop. The customers come from only three locations “X”, “Y”, “Z”. Moreover, the customers who visits the shop predominantly come by either “Car”, “Scooty” or “Bus” (Note: customers who come from X, Y and Z can use other modes as well). The footfall in the store indicates that 40% of the customers are from “X” and another 40% from “Y”. The remaining customers come from “Z”.  It is observed that, of the people in location “X”, 30% own only a “scooter” and travel to the store only by scooty to the store, 60% own only a “Car” and travel to the store only by car. In location “Y”, 40% own only a “Car” and travel to the store only by car, 20% own only a “Scooty” and travel to the store only by scooty, and 20% are eco-friendly and travel only by “Bus” to the store. In location “Z”, 50% own a “Scooty” and travel only by scooty to the store, 40% are eco-friendly and travel only by “Bus” to the store. Moreover, all the people living in location “X” are rich and never opt to travel to the store by “Bus”. On the contrary, the people in location “C” do not own a “Car” and never visit the store by “Car”.  Assuming the necessary mutual exclusiveness, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: A retailer has data pertaining to customers who visit the shop. The customers come from only three locations “X”, “Y”, “Z”. Moreover, the customers who visits the shop predominantly come by either “Car”, “Scooty” or “Bus” (Note: customers who come from X, Y and Z can use other modes as well). The footfall in the store indicates that 40% of the customers are from “X” and another 40% from “Y”. The remaining customers come from “Z”.  It is observed that, of the people in location “X”, 30% own only a “scooter” and travel to the store only by scooty to the store, 60% own only a “Car” and travel to the store only by car. In location “Y”, 40% own only a “Car” and travel to the store only by car, 20% own only a “Scooty” and travel to the store only by scooty, and 20% are eco-friendly and travel only by “Bus” to the store. In location “Z”, 50% own a “Scooty” and travel only by scooty to the store, 40% are eco-friendly and travel only by “Bus” to the store. Moreover, all the people living in location “X” are rich and never opt to travel to the store by “Bus”. On the contrary, the people in location “C” do not own a “Car” and never visit the store by “Car”.  Assuming the necessary mutual exclusiveness, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: The retailer is planning spend money on creating a parking space (for “Cars” and “Scooties”). Once the space is built, every day a total of 600 customers are expected. Then, what is the expected parking revenue generated from location “X” if the parking charges are set at Rs. 20 for a parking a car and Rs. 10 for parking a two-wheeler?

questions.question_text_1: The demand for cycles at IITM during the admission season is seen to follow the linear demand response curve D(p) = 300000 – 13*P. For the coming academic year, the bicycle shop at IITM is going to procure bicycles from a manufacturer at Rs. 8000/ cycle  Then answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: The demand for cycles at IITM during the admission season is seen to follow the linear demand response curve D(p) = 300000 – 13*P. For the coming academic year, the bicycle shop at IITM is going to procure bicycles from a manufacturer at Rs. 8000/ cycle  Then answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: A kirana store owner has allocated a budget of Rs. 21000 to buy fruits to sell in the store. The aim of the owner is to maximize the revenue from selling fruits. The owner has decided to buy “Apples”, “Oranges”, “Mangoes” and “Banana”. The Apples are purchased at Rs. 20/piece, the Oranges at Rs. 8/piece, Mangos at Rs. 12/piece and Bananas at Rs. 2/piece. An apple is sold for Rs. 25/piece, Orange at Rs. 18/piece, Mango at Rs. 22/piece and Banana at Rs. 5/piece. Due to physical considerations, the owner cannot buy more than 800 Apples, 500 Oranges, 600 Mangoes and 700 Bananas. Additionally, the number of Apples purchased must be at least 30% more than the number of Bananas purchased. The number of Oranges purchased must be equal to the number of Mangoes purchased. Finally, total number of fruit pieces that an owner can buy is cannot be more than 2000.  Given this information, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: A kirana store owner has allocated a budget of Rs. 21000 to buy fruits to sell in the store. The aim of the owner is to maximize the revenue from selling fruits. The owner has decided to buy “Apples”, “Oranges”, “Mangoes” and “Banana”. The Apples are purchased at Rs. 20/piece, the Oranges at Rs. 8/piece, Mangos at Rs. 12/piece and Bananas at Rs. 2/piece. An apple is sold for Rs. 25/piece, Orange at Rs. 18/piece, Mango at Rs. 22/piece and Banana at Rs. 5/piece. Due to physical considerations, the owner cannot buy more than 800 Apples, 500 Oranges, 600 Mangoes and 700 Bananas. Additionally, the number of Apples purchased must be at least 30% more than the number of Bananas purchased. The number of Oranges purchased must be equal to the number of Mangoes purchased. Finally, total number of fruit pieces that an owner can buy is cannot be more than 2000.  Given this information, answer the given subquestions.

Due to physical considerations, the owner cannot buy more than 800 Apples, 500 Oranges, 600 Mangoes and 700 Bananas. Additionally, the number of Apples purchased must be at least 30% more than the number of Bananas purchased. The number of Oranges purchased must be equal to the number of Mangoes purchased. Finally, total number of fruit pieces that an owner can buy is cannot be more than 2000.  Given this information, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: A kirana store owner has allocated a budget of Rs. 21000 to buy fruits to sell in the store. The aim of the owner is to maximize the revenue from selling fruits. The owner has decided to buy “Apples”, “Oranges”, “Mangoes” and “Banana”. The Apples are purchased at Rs. 20/piece, the Oranges at Rs. 8/piece, Mangos at Rs. 12/piece and Bananas at Rs. 2/piece. An apple is sold for Rs. 25/piece, Orange at Rs. 18/piece, Mango at Rs. 22/piece and Banana at Rs. 5/piece. Additionally, the number of Apples purchased must be at least 30% more than the number of Bananas purchased. The number of Oranges purchased must be equal to the number of Mangoes purchased. Finally, total number of fruit pieces that an owner can buy is cannot be more than 2000.  Given this information, answer the given subquestions.

By moving vertically towards the frontier
By drawing a line connecting the origin and DMU
None of these

question_texts: In conjoint analysis, the objective function of the linear programming model using pair-wise judgments:

Minimize the goodness of fit
Minimize the poorness of fit
Both Maximize the distance from the ideal point and Minimize the goodness offit
Both Maximize the distance from the ideal point and Minimize the poorness offit

options.option_text: After converting the ratio into the linear objective function
After normalizing the denominator
By setting a constraint on the efficiency of all DMUs to be greater than or equalto 1
All of these

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts**
### **1. Statistical Hypothesis Testing (Chi-Square Test for Uniformity)**
- **Objective**: Test if data follows a uniform distribution.
- **Key Steps**:
  1. **Bin Data**: Divide data into intervals (bins).
  2. **Expected Frequency (E)**:
     - For uniform distribution: \( E = \frac{\text{Total Observations}}{\text{Number of Bins}} \).
     - Example: For 15 days and 4 bins, \( E = \frac{15}{4} = 3.75 \) (Q2).
  3. **Degrees of Freedom (df)**:
     - \( \text{df} = \text{Number of Bins} - 1 - \text{Estimated Parameters} \).
     - For uniform distribution (no parameters estimated): \( \text{df} = 4 - 1 = 3 \).
     - **Note**: Q3 answer is 1 (likely a typo; should be 3 for 4 bins).
  4. **Chi-Square Statistic**:
     \[
     \chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_i - E_i)^2}{E_i}
     \]
     - \( O_i \): Observed frequency in bin \( i \).
     - \( E_i \): Expected frequency in bin \( i \).
     - Example: Q4 answer (~9.75).
  5. **Decision Rule**:
     - Reject \( H_0 \) (uniformity) if \( \chi^2 > \chi^2_{\text{critical}} \).
     - Example: Q5 (Reject \( H_0 \) since 9.75 < 10.59 is false; correct answer is **C**).

---

### **2. Independence Testing (Chi-Square Test for Independence)**
- **Objective**: Test if two categorical variables (e.g., sales in Street-A and Street-B) are independent.
- **Key Steps**:
  1. **Contingency Table**: Cross-tabulate observed frequencies.
  2. **Expected Frequency (E)**:
     \[
     E_{ij} = \frac{(\text{Row Total}_i) \times (\text{Column Total}_j)}{\text{Grand Total}}
     \]
     - Example: Q7 (Day-10, Street-B expected sales ~107.69).
  3. **Degrees of Freedom (df)**:
     \[
     \text{df} = (\text{Rows} - 1) \times (\text{Columns} - 1)
     \]
     - For 15 days × 2 streets: \( \text{df} = (15-1)(2-1) = 14 \) (Q6).
  4. **Chi-Square Statistic**: Same as above.

---

### **3. Probability & Conditional Probability**
- **Total Probability Rule**:
  \[
  P(A) = \sum P(A|B_i) \cdot P(B_i)
  \]
  - Example: Q9 (Probability of arriving by Scooty = 0.38).
- **Expected Value**:
  \[
  E[X] = \sum x_i \cdot P(x_i)
  \]
  - Example: Q10 (Expected Bus travelers = 400 × 0.16 = 64).

---

### **4. Revenue & Profit Optimization**
- **Revenue Maximization**:
  - **Demand Function**: \( D(p) = 300000 - 13p \).
  - **Revenue**: \( R(p) = p \cdot D(p) = p(300000 - 13p) \).
  - **Optimal Price**: Maximize \( R(p) \) by setting derivative to zero:
    \[
    \frac{dR}{dp} = 300000 - 26p = 0 \implies p = \frac{300000}{26} \approx 11538.46 \text{ (Q13)}
    \]
- **Profit Maximization**:
  - **Profit**: \( \Pi(p) = R(p) - \text{Total Cost} = p(300000 - 13p) - 8000(300000 - 13p) \).
  - **Optimal Price**: Set \( \frac{d\Pi}{dp} = 0 \):
    \[
    \frac{d\Pi}{dp} = 300000 - 26p - (-104000) = 0 \implies p \approx 15538.46 \text{ (Q14)}
    \]

---

### **5. Linear Programming (LP)**
- **Primal Problem** (Kirana Store):
  - **Objective**: Maximize revenue:
    \[
    \text{Max } Z = 25A + 18O + 22M + 5B
    \]
  - **Constraints**:
    1. Budget: \( 20A + 8O + 12M + 2B \leq 21000 \).
    2. Quantity limits: \( A \leq 800 \), \( O \leq 500 \), \( M \leq 600 \), \( B \leq 700 \).
    3. \( A \geq 1.3B \).
    4. \( O = M \).
    5. Total fruits: \( A + O + M + B \leq 2000 \).
  - **Decision Variables**: 4 (A, O, M, B) (Q15).
- **Dual Problem**:
  - **Decision Variables**: Equal to primal constraints (9) (Q16).
  - **RHS of Dual**: Coefficients of primal objective (25, 18, 22, 5) (Q17).
- **Binding Constraints**:
  - If a constraint is tight (equality holds), its dual variable is non-zero.
  - Example: Q18 (4 binding constraints for given solution).

---

### **6. Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA)**
- **Efficiency Measurement**:
  - **Efficiency Score**: \( \text{Efficiency} = \frac{\text{Weighted Output}}{\text{Weighted Input}} \).
  - **LP Formulation**: Convert ratio to linear form using **Charnes-Cooper Transformation** (Q25).
- **Hypothetical Composite Unit**:
  - Graphical method: Draw line from origin to DMU (Q23).
- **Shadow Price**:
  - Change in objective value per unit change in resource (Q22).

---

### **7. Conjoint Analysis**
- **Objective**: Understand consumer preferences for product attributes.
- **Types**:
  - **Choice-Based Conjoint (CBC)**: Consumers choose among full-profile options (Q28).
  - **Statistical/Regression Approach**: Uses **ratings data** (Q26).
- **Model Objective**:
  - Minimize "poorness of fit" (Q24).

---

### **8. Classification Model Evaluation**
- **Metrics**:
  - **Accuracy**: \( \frac{\text{TP} + \text{TN}}{\text{Total}} \) (Q29: 64.29%).
  - **Precision (Class 1)**: \( \frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP} + \text{FP}} \) (Q30: 71.43%).
  - **Recall (Class 1)**: \( \frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP} + \text{FN}} \) (Q31: 62.5%).
  - **Precision (Class 0)**: \( \frac{\text{TN}}{\text{TN} + \text{FP}} \) (Q32: 57.14%).
  - **Recall (Class 0)**: \( \frac{\text{TN}}{\text{TN} + \text{FN}} \) (Q33: 66.67%).

---

## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **1. Statistical Testing Relationships**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Hypothesis Testing] --> B[Chi-Square Test]
    B --> C[Uniformity Test]
    B --> D[Independence Test]
    C --> E[Expected Frequency]
    C --> F[Degrees of Freedom]
    C --> G[Chi-Square Statistic]
    D --> H[Contingency Table]
    D --> I[Expected Frequency Calculation]
    D --> J[Degrees of Freedom]
```

### **2. Probability & Optimization**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Probability] --> B[Total Probability Rule]
    A --> C[Expected Value]
    B --> D[Conditional Probability]
    C --> E[Revenue Calculation]
    E --> F[Demand Function]
    F --> G[Revenue Maximization]
    F --> H[Profit Maximization]
```

### **3. Linear Programming & DEA**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Linear Programming] --> B[Primal Problem]
    A --> C[Dual Problem]
    B --> D[Objective Function]
    B --> E[Constraints]
    C --> F[Decision Variables]
    C --> G[Shadow Prices]
    A --> H[DEA]
    H --> I[Efficiency Score]
    H --> J[LP Formulation]
```

### **4. Conjoint Analysis & Classification**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Conjoint Analysis] --> B[Choice-Based]
    A --> C[Regression-Based]
    B --> D[Consumer Preferences]
    C --> E[Ratings Data]
    A --> F[Model Objective]
    F --> G[Minimize Poorness of Fit]
    H[Classification Metrics] --> I[Accuracy]
    H --> J[Precision]
    H --> K[Recall]
```
